messageBody:
> What I really wanted to do was create a FooSpecialTest that extends
> FooTest and just reimplements getFoo. Unfortunately, that does not
> work (the error is '1) warning(junit.framework.TestSuite$1) "No tests
> found in FooSpecialTest"').

That works fine for me. However, I extended the TestCase instead.

Here's the code (slightly modified :-) Let me know if it solves your
problem.

Bye,
Robert

public abstract class FooTestCase extends TestCase
{
public FooTestCase( String name )
{
super( name );
}

abstract protected Foo getFoo();

// here come the test cases...
}

and two test classes. I'll spare you the second one, though :-)

public class SpecialFooTest extends FooTestCase
{
public SpecialFooTest( String name )
{
super( name );
}

protected Foo getFoo()
{
return new FooSpecialImpl();
}

public static Test suite( )
{
return new TestSuite( SpecialFooTest.class );
}

// Add FooSpecialImpl specific tests here.
}
